column4: can anyone help me with editing /etc/fstab ? I addedd two hard disks but I still cannot see them automounted when I reboot -
if you added two harddisks then you can only mount partitionson those disks.  Do they have file systems on them and are you pointing to the right partition?
vox754 can I paste my fstab? can you (want) to look at it ?
you don't need the umask on the 40.  You could try it with just defaults.  Do a manual mount: mount /dev/hdc1 /media/HD40
alright, you have your partitions wrong it looks like.
you'll see /dev/hdc1 is your windows partion (NTFS)
and you'll see your largest partition on hdd is of type linux.
and you probably don't care about hdd1.
I mounted manually the HD40GB it worked
you can run just 'mount' to see all the partitions that are mounted and what file systems they are.
it shows the HD40GB is ext3  - and now since I mounted manually it worked - I wonder what do I need to change in fstab to automatically mount it when reboot
that's hdc1 that's mounted as the 40G?
yes, is the HD40GB which I want to mount
seems strange that it's mounting as ext3 when your fdisk says it's NTFS.  I'd go with vox on this one.
and vox: both the 40GB and 160GB were formated with NTFS before - however I reformated them as ext3
so if you unmount it, will the following command mount it? mount -t ext3 /dev/hdc1 /media/HD40GB
I mounted before without -t ext3 - should I unmount first ?
I just want to test that it works with an ext3 as an explicit mount.  If it does then it should work with a line of '/dev/hdc1   /media/HD40GB   ext3  defaults  0  0'
it probably has a gid partition table on there.  I'm not sure how easy it is to convert that to an fdisk layout or how well it works with the kernel.
Apple loves to do everything their own way.  At leas they're including ZFS.
I don't know of any graphical utilities.  I'm a console jockey.
thanks for all your help
